value.title: Create a bump or slope chart in Power BI -D70
value.excerpt: Bump or slope charts are useful to sport changes between categories. There is no native bump or slope visual in Power BI, but you can create your own easily from a line chart. In this video I show you how. #curbal #power bi #bumpcharts  Here you can download the file (#70) here: https://curbal.com/donwload-center

value.title: Create an excel based budget app with PowerApps and use it in Power BI
value.excerpt: In today's video I will walk though how to create your first powerapp using excel and onedrive as a source.  The app will be a budget file app that we will them import into Power BI for further analysis, both the data and the app√∂  The possibilities are endeless!! Enjoy!    Looking for a download file?

value.title: DAX Fridays! #14: SUMMARIZE
value.excerpt: Learn how to use the function SUMMARIZE in DAX/ Powerpivot.  The function SUMMARIZE can return a summary of sales grouped around the calendar year and the product category name, this result table allows you to do analysis over the reseller sales by year and product category.  Source:https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg492171.aspx

value.title: DAX Fridays! #21: USERELATIONSHIP
value.excerpt: A common example in a Power BI table is to have multiple dates, which are related to the same Date table. As you are limited to one active relationship, we need to use the DAX function USERELATIONSHIP to manage the inactive relationships.  Link to Power BI file: https://curbal.com/blog/glossary/userelationship-dax
